diagnoses: Drug-related eosinophilia with systemic symptoms (DRESS) syndrome
Drug Reaction with Eosinophilia and Systemic Symptoms (DRESS) Syndrome
Drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS) syndrome

Drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS) syndrome
Drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS syndrome)

diagnoses.name: Kawasaki Disease
diagnoses.description: A condition that causes inflammation in the walls of some blood vessels in the body. It's more common in children. The symptoms you've described align closely, especially when considering fever, hand erythema, and conjunctivitis.

diagnoses.name: Adult Still's Disease
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory disease that leads to fever, rash, and joint pain. Hand erythema can be a component of the rash, leukocytosis is common, and anemia and conjunctivitis might also be present.

diagnoses.name: Leukemia
diagnoses.description: A type of cancer of the body's blood-forming tissues, including the bone marrow and the lymphatic system. Symptoms can include fever, anemia, and leukocytosis.

diagnoses.name: Infectious Mononucleosis
diagnoses.description: Often caused by the Epstein-Barr virus, it's a contagious illness sometimes called mono or 'the kissing disease.' It can cause fever, leukocytosis, and in some cases, anemia.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatic Fever
diagnoses.description: A disease that can develop from strep throat. It's not common in developed countries today. Symptoms often include fever, leukocytosis, and sometimes anemia and skin symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.description: A chronic autoimmune condition that can affect the joints, skin, brain, lungs, kidneys, and blood vessels, causing widespread inflammation and tissue damage in the affected organs. Symptoms can include anemia and leukocytosis.

diagnoses.name: Sepsis
diagnoses.description: A life-threatening condition caused by the body's response to an infection. Symptoms can include fever, leukocytosis, and in more severe cases, anemia.

diagnoses.name: Scarlet Fever
diagnoses.description: An infection that can develop in people who have strep throat. It's characterized by a bright red rash on the body, fever, and sometimes, anemia.

diagnoses.name: Inflammatory Bowel Disease (IBD)
diagnoses.description: A term for two conditions (Crohn's disease and ulcerative colitis) that are characterized by chronic inflammation of the gastrointestinal tract. Symptoms can include anemia and leukocytosis.

diagnoses.name: Henoch-Schönlein Purpura (HSP)
diagnoses.description: An inflammation of small blood vessels that can cause them to bleed into the skin, joints, intestines, and kidneys. Hand erythema, conjunctivitis, and anemia can be part of the presentation.

diagnoses: Drug Reaction with Eosinophilia and Systemic Symptoms (DRESS)
Drug Reaction with Eosinophilia and Systemic Symptoms (DRESS) Syndrome
Drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS) syndrome
Schizophrenia (in cases of lupus with neuropsychiatric manifestations)
Viral infection (e.g., HIV, hepatitis B, hepatitis C)
Attention Deficit Hyperactivity Disorder (ADHD) with comorbid conditions

diagnoses.name: Celiac Disease
diagnoses.reasoning: Reflects a potential underlying cause of malabsorption, depression, and might be associated with elevated immunoglobulin levels, particularly IgA against tissue transglutaminase. Dermatitis herpetiformis, related to celiac, can sometimes be confused with or occur alongside eczema.

diagnoses.name: Inflammatory Bowel Disease
diagnoses.reasoning: Can cause malabsorption, depression due to chronic illness, and skin conditions such as eczema. Some forms might also be associated with increased immunoglobulins due to the ongoing inflammation.

diagnoses.name: Sjögren's Syndrome
diagnoses.reasoning: An autoimmune disorder that may present with increased immunoglobulins and can accompany symptoms such as dry eyes (possibly leading to blepharospasm) and skin manifestations. Depression is a common comorbidity with chronic illnesses.

diagnoses.name: IgG4-Related Disease
diagnoses.reasoning: A fibroinflammatory condition that can lead to elevated levels of immunoglobulin G4 (IgG4). It can affect multiple organs, potentially explaining a wide range of symptoms although less commonly associated with the specific combination.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Fatigue Syndrome
diagnoses.reasoning: While not directly associated with increased immunoglobulins, it is a condition that can encompass a wide range of symptoms including malabsorption and depression. Skin issues and eye discomfort might also be noted by patients.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis
diagnoses.reasoning: An autoimmune disease of the central nervous system that can lead to a wide array of symptoms including depression. The link to this specific symptom set is less direct, but MS can have diverse and widespread effects on the body.

diagnoses.name: Hypothyroidism
diagnoses.reasoning: Can cause depression and has been associated with skin conditions. Hypothyroidism can also affect absorption and, in rare cases, be linked with immune system irregularities.

diagnoses.name: Lupus
diagnoses.reasoning: Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) can cause a wide range of symptoms including skin conditions, depression, and is associated with autoimmune activity that may explain elevated immunoglobulins.

diagnoses.name: Psychological Stress
diagnoses.reasoning: While not a 'medical diagnosis' in the traditional sense, stress can exacerbate or mimic symptoms of various physical conditions, including skin issues like eczema, depression, and even gastrointestinal problems.

diagnoses.name: Nutritional Deficiency
diagnoses.reasoning: Deficiencies in certain vitamins or minerals due to malabsorption can lead to a variety of symptoms including skin conditions and depression. Over time, it could possibly impact immune function.

symptoms: dyspnea with normal pulmonary function tests

diagnoses.name: Sjögren's Syndrome
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease that often features symptoms such as dry eyes, dry mouth, and can affect other parts of the body, including skin and internal organs. It may also lead to lymphadenopathy.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.description: A chronic autoimmune disease that can cause inflammation and damage to various body parts including joints, skin, kidneys, blood cells, brain, heart, and lungs. Symptoms can include dry eyes, lymphadenitis, and migratory edema.

diagnoses.name: Sarcoidosis
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory disease that affects multiple organs in the body, but mostly the lungs and lymph glands. Symptoms can include dry eyes, lymphadenopathy, and skin rashes.

diagnoses.name: HIV/AIDS
diagnoses.description: A virus that attacks the immune system. Advanced stages can present with symptoms such as lymphadenitis, and other symptoms might include dry eyes due to general immune suppression.

diagnoses.name: Behçet's Disease
diagnoses.description: A rare disorder causing blood vessel inflammation throughout your body. Symptoms include irritated eyes, mouth sores, skin rashes, and swollen glands.

diagnoses.name: Churg-Strauss Syndrome
diagnoses.description: Now called Eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis, it is a disorder marked by inflammation of blood vessels and tissues in the body. Symptoms can include migratory edema and eye discomfort.

diagnoses.name: IgG4-related Disease
diagnoses.description: A rare immune-mediated condition that can cause fibrosis and swelling in various organs, including the lacrimal and salivary glands, leading to symptoms such as dry eyes and lymphadenopathy.

diagnoses.name: Celiac Disease
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disorder where the ingestion of gluten leads to damage in the small intestine, causing malabsorption among other symptoms. Although less common, it may lead to systemic manifestations including migratory edema.

diagnoses.name: Tuberculosis
diagnoses.description: A bacterial infection that affects the lungs but can also spread to other parts of the body. It might cause lymphadenitis and systemic symptoms including malabsorption in disseminated cases.

diagnoses.name: Lyme Disease
diagnoses.description: An infectious disease caused by the Borrelia bacterium which is spread by ticks. Symptoms can include migratory edema, lymphadenopathy, and, in some cases, eye inflammation.

diagnoses.name: Allergic reaction
diagnoses.description: An exaggerated response of the immune system to a substance, which can cause symptoms like angioedema, wheezing, and irritability.

diagnoses.name: Anaphylaxis
diagnoses.description: A serious, life-threatening allergic reaction that can cause wheezing, angioedema, and increased irritability due to decreased oxygen.

diagnoses.name: Asthma
diagnoses.description: A condition in which your airways narrow and swell and may produce extra mucus, leading to wheezing and irritability.

diagnoses.name: Inflammatory bowel disease (IBD)
diagnoses.description: A term for two conditions (Crohn's disease and ulcerative colitis) that are characterized by chronic inflammation of the gastrointestinal (GI) tract, potentially causing hemorrhoids.

diagnoses.name: Drug reaction
diagnoses.description: Adverse effects of medication, which can cause symptoms including angioedema, leukocytosis, and irritability.

diagnoses.name: Food allergy
diagnoses.description: An immune system reaction that occurs soon after eating a certain food, causing symptoms like angioedema and wheezing.

diagnoses.name: Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD)
diagnoses.description: A chronic inflammatory lung disease that causes obstructed airflow from the lungs, resulting in wheezing and potentially leading to leukocytosis due to chronic inflammation.

diagnoses.name: Urticaria (Hives)
diagnoses.description: A skin rash triggered by a reaction to food, medicine, or other irritants, potentially causing angioedema and irritability.

diagnoses.name: Hereditary angioedema
diagnoses.description: A rare, genetic condition causing swelling, particularly of the face and airways, and abdominal cramping.

diagnoses.name: Leukemia
diagnoses.description: A type of cancer of the blood and bone marrow that affects white blood cells and causes leukocytosis along with other symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Head and Neck Cancer
diagnoses.description: A group of cancers that start within the mouth, voice box, throat, salivary glands, nasal cavity, or paranasal sinuses. Symptoms include lymphadenopathy, dysphagia (difficulty swallowing), and potential airway obstruction leading to sleep apnea.

diagnoses.name: Lymphoma
diagnoses.description: A type of cancer that begins in the lymphatic system. Lymphadenopathy (swollen lymph nodes) is a common symptom. Other related symptoms might include general fatigue and signs of infection.

diagnoses.name: Infectious Mononucleosis (Mono)
diagnoses.description: Caused by the Epstein-Barr virus, symptoms include swollen lymph nodes, sore throat, fatigue, and atypical manifestations can include obstruction of the airway, leading to difficulties like obstructive sleep apnea.

diagnoses.name: Sarcoidosis
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory disease that affects multiple organs, particularly the lungs and lymph glands. Symptoms can include lymphadenopathy and dysphagia if the mediastinal lymph nodes are involved.

diagnoses.name: Thyroiditis
diagnoses.description: Inflammation of the thyroid gland that can cause swelling at the front of the throat. Some forms, like Hashimoto’s thyroiditis, can be associated with a variety of symptoms, including potentially affecting swallowing due to gland enlargement.

diagnoses.name: Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis
diagnoses.description: A rare disorder causing inflammation of the blood vessels in your nose, sinuses, throat, lungs, and kidneys. Ear problems such as otitis externa and systemic issues like lymphadenopathy can occur.

diagnoses.name: HIV/AIDS
diagnoses.description: Human Immunodeficiency Virus affects the immune system and can cause widespread symptoms, including lymphadenopathy. Otitis externa, and various secondary infections may occur due to the compromised immune system.

diagnoses.name: Gastroesophageal Reflux Disease (GERD)
diagnoses.description: A digestive disorder that affects the lower esophageal sphincter. While primarily associated with heartburn and acid reflux, severe cases can impact swallowing and potentially contribute to sleep apnea through mechanisms like airway inflammation.

diagnoses.name: Eagle Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A rare condition where the styloid process is elongated and/or the stylohyoid ligament is calcified. It can cause dysphagia, otalgia, and referred pain in the face and throat.

diagnoses.name: Tuberculosis
diagnoses.description: A contagious infection caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis. Lymphadenopathy is a common finding, especially in extrapulmonary tuberculosis, and it can occasionally cause dysphagia if lymph nodes compress the esophagus.

diagnoses.name: Sjögren's Syndrome
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disorder characterized by dry eyes and mouth, which could be associated with systemic features such as hypergammaglobulinemia (increased immunoglobulins) and can cause gastrointestinal symptoms including diarrhea.

diagnoses.name: Primary Immunodeficiency Disorders
diagnoses.description: A group of disorders where part of the body's immune system is missing or does not function properly. Some of these disorders may present with both increased and decreased levels of immunoglobulins, and can be associated with diarrhea and other systemic symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Hyperthyroidism
diagnoses.description: A condition where the thyroid gland is overactive, leading to an excess of thyroid hormones. Symptoms can include diarrhea and hyperactivity. Autoimmune thyroid disease can also be associated with other autoimmune conditions like Sjögren's Syndrome which could explain dry eyes.

diagnoses.name: Autoimmune Polyendocrine Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A rare condition involving multiple endocrine gland deficiencies. It is associated with autoimmune manifestations which can include symptoms such as hyperactivity due to thyroid involvement, diarrhea, dry eyes, and dysregulated immunoglobulin levels.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease that affects many parts of the body, including joints, skin, kidneys, and the nervous system. Patients can exhibit a wide range of symptoms including dry eyes, hyperactivity, diarrhea, and abnormalities in immunoglobulin levels.

diagnoses.name: Common Variable Immune Deficiency (CVID)
diagnoses.description: A disorder characterized by decreased levels of several immunoglobulin classes, leading to an increased susceptibility to infection. Paradoxically, patients can also have elevated levels of some immunoglobulins. Symptoms can include gastrointestinal issues like diarrhea.

diagnoses.name: Celiac Disease
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disorder where ingestion of gluten leads to damage in the small intestine, causing diarrhea. It can be associated with other autoimmune disorders that could explain symptoms like dry eyes and dysregulation of immunoglobulins.

diagnoses.name: Giardiasis
diagnoses.description: An intestinal infection caused by the protozoan Giardia lamblia, leading to diarrhea. It's not directly associated with the other symptoms but could occur concurrently or complicate an underlying systemic or immunological condition.

diagnoses.name: IgG4-Related Disease
diagnoses.description: A fibroinflammatory condition characterized by often elevated levels of IgG4-positive plasma cells. Symptoms can vary widely but include chronic diarrhea, dry eyes, and variable effects on immunoglobulin levels.

diagnoses.name: HIV/AIDS
diagnoses.description: Human Immunodeficiency Virus (HIV) infection can lead to Acquired Immune Deficiency Syndrome (AIDS), which can disrupt normal immunoglobulin production leading to both increased and decreased levels. Gastrointestinal symptoms like diarrhea and systemic symptoms such as hyperactivity due to neurological involvement can occur.

diagnoses.name: Migraine
diagnoses.description: A neurological condition that can cause multiple symptoms. It's frequently characterized by intense, debilitating headaches. Symptoms may include nausea, vomiting, difficulty speaking, numbness or tingling, and sensitivity to light and sound.

diagnoses.name: Stroke
diagnoses.description: Occurs when the blood supply to part of your brain is interrupted or reduced, preventing brain tissue from getting oxygen and nutrients. Brain cells begin to die in minutes. A stroke is a medical emergency, and prompt treatment is crucial.

diagnoses.name: Meningitis
diagnoses.description: An inflammation of the fluid and membranes (meninges) surrounding your brain and spinal cord. The swelling from meningitis typically triggers symptoms such as headache, fever, and a stiff neck.

diagnoses.name: Meniere's Disease
diagnoses.description: A disorder of the inner ear that can lead to dizzy spells (vertigo) and hearing loss. In most cases, Meniere's disease affects only one ear.

diagnoses.name: Brain Tumor
diagnoses.description: A mass or growth of abnormal cells in your brain. Many different types of brain tumors exist. Some brain tumors are noncancerous (benign), and some brain tumors are cancerous (malignant).

diagnoses.name: Acoustic Neuroma
diagnoses.description: Also known as vestibular schwannoma, is a noncancerous and usually slow-growing tumor that develops on the main nerve leading from your inner ear to your brain.

diagnoses.name: Temporal Arteritis
diagnoses.description: An inflammation of blood vessels, called arteries, in and around the scalp. Symptoms of temporal arteritis include persistent headache, scalp tenderness, jaw pain, vision problems, and hearing loss.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis
diagnoses.description: A disease of the central nervous system that can cause symptoms throughout the body. It's believed to be an autoimmune condition, where the immune system mistakenly attacks healthy parts of the body. Symptoms can include fatigue, difficulty walking, numbness, and muscle stiffness.

diagnoses.name: Viral Encephalitis
diagnoses.description: An inflammation of the brain caused by a virus. Symptoms can include headache, fever, confusion, drowsiness, and fatigue.

diagnoses.name: Lyme Disease
diagnoses.description: An infectious disease caused by the bacterium Borrelia burgdorferi spread by ticks. Early symptoms may include fever, headache, and fatigue, while later symptoms may include a rash, arthritis, facial paralysis, and meningitis.

diagnoses.name: Stroke
diagnoses.description: A condition where poor blood flow to the brain results in cell death, causing symptoms like weakness and aphasia.

diagnoses.name: Brain tumor
diagnoses.description: An abnormal growth of cells within the brain, which can cause symptoms like vomiting, weakness, and language disturbances.

diagnoses.name: Migraine
diagnoses.description: A type of headache characterized by severe pain, nausea, and sensitivity to light, sometimes preceded by aura, including symptoms like speech disturbances.

diagnoses.name: Gastroenteritis
diagnoses.description: An intestinal infection marked by diarrhea, cramps, nausea, vomiting, and fever.

diagnoses.name: Multiple sclerosis
diagnoses.description: A disease in which the immune system eats away at the protective covering of nerves, causing weakness and could potentially lead to speech difficulties.

diagnoses.name: Encephalitis
diagnoses.description: Inflammation of the brain, caused by infection or an autoimmune response, leading to symptoms like fever, weakness, confusion, and problems with speech or hearing.

diagnoses.name: Meningitis
diagnoses.description: An inflammation of the brain and spinal cord membranes, typically caused by an infection. Symptoms can include vomiting, weakness, and difficulty speaking.

diagnoses.name: Hypoglycemia
diagnoses.description: A condition caused by a very low level of blood sugar (glucose), leading to symptoms like weakness, tiredness, and could potentially cause neurological symptoms if severe.

diagnoses.name: Dehydration
diagnoses.description: A condition that occurs when you use or lose more fluid than you take in, and your body doesn't have enough water and other fluids to carry out its normal functions; may lead to weakness and vomiting.

diagnoses.name: Transient ischemic attack (TIA)
diagnoses.description: Often called a 'mini-stroke,' a TIA is a brief period of symptoms similar to those in a stroke, such as weakness and speech disturbance, but usually does not leave lasting damage.

diagnoses.name: Stroke
diagnoses.description: A medical condition that occurs when the blood supply to part of the brain is interrupted or reduced, preventing brain tissue from getting oxygen and nutrients. Symptoms can include difficulty speaking, paralysis, or numbness in the face, arm, or leg, and vision problems.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis
diagnoses.description: A chronic autoimmune disease that affects the central nervous system, leading to symptoms like double vision, weakness, balance issues, and difficulty in speech.

diagnoses.name: Brain Tumor
diagnoses.description: Abnormal cell growth in the brain which can be benign or malignant. Symptoms might include headaches, seizures, vision problems, speech difficulties, and changes in personality.

diagnoses.name: Myasthenia Gravis
diagnoses.description: A chronic autoimmune neuromuscular disease that causes weakness in the skeletal muscles responsible for breathing and moving parts of the body, including the eyes. Symptoms include double vision, drooping eyelids, and difficulties with speech, chewing, and swallowing.

diagnoses.name: Transient Ischemic Attack (TIA)
diagnoses.description: Often called a mini-stroke, a TIA is a brief period of symptoms similar to those of a stroke. Symptoms can include dysphagia, aphasia, and vision problems like diplopia and scotoma but typically resolve within minutes to hours without permanent brain damage.

diagnoses.name: Migraine with Aura
diagnoses.description: A common type of headache disorder that can be preceded or accompanied by sensory warning signs such as flashes of light, blind spots, or other vision changes, alongside speech disturbances.

diagnoses.name: Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis (ALS)
diagnoses.description: A progressive neurodegenerative disease that affects nerve cells in the brain and the spinal cord, leading to muscle weakness and atrophy. Symptoms can include difficulties in speaking, swallowing, and eventually breathing.

diagnoses.name: Guillain-Barré Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A rare disorder in which the body's immune system attacks the nerves. Weakness and tingling in the extremities are usually the first symptoms. These sensations can quickly spread, eventually paralyzing the whole body, and can lead to difficulties with facial movement, including speech and swallowing.

diagnoses.name: Brain Abscess
diagnoses.description: A collection of pus that develops in response to infection or trauma. Symptoms can mimic those of a brain tumor, including headaches, neurological deficits, seizures, and vision problems, such as diplopia or scotoma.

diagnoses.name: Acute Disseminated Encephalomyelitis (ADEM)
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory condition that affects the brain and spinal cord. It often follows viral or bacterial infections and is characterized by a sudden onset of neurological symptoms, including vision loss, weakness, and difficulty speaking or swallowing.

diagnoses.name: Migraine with aura
diagnoses.description: Migraines are headaches with throbbing pain that are usually on one side of the head. In migraines with aura, there are sensory disturbances (like scintillations, zigzag lines) that precede the headache phase.

diagnoses.name: Vertebrobasilar insufficiency
diagnoses.description: This condition occurs when there's inadequate blood flow through the back of the brain. Symptoms can include vertigo, dizziness, headache, and nausea.

diagnoses.name: Meniere's disease
diagnoses.description: Meniere's disease affects the inner ear and causes vertigo, hearing loss, tinnitus, and a feeling of fullness or congestion in the ear.

diagnoses.name: Vestibular migraine
diagnoses.description: This is a type of migraine that may or may not cause a headache but includes mainly vestibular symptoms like vertigo, dizziness, and balance problems.

diagnoses.name: Transient ischemic attack (TIA)
diagnoses.description: Commonly known as a 'mini-stroke,' a TIA can cause symptoms similar to a stroke (including headache, vertigo, and nausea) but typically lasts only a few minutes and leaves no permanent damage.

diagnoses.name: Benign positional vertigo (BPV)
diagnoses.description: BPV is a disorder arising from a problem in the inner ear, characterized by brief episodes of mild to intense dizziness associated with specific changes in the position of your head.

diagnoses.name: Stroke
diagnoses.description: A stroke occurs when the blood supply to part of your brain is interrupted, depriving brain tissue of oxygen and nutrients. Symptoms can include headache, vertigo, confusion, and nausea.

diagnoses.name: Brain tumor
diagnoses.description: Brain tumors can cause symptoms depending on their location. Common symptoms include headaches that worsen in the morning, nausea, vertigo, and visual disturbances.

diagnoses.name: Multiple sclerosis
diagnoses.description: Multiple sclerosis (MS) is a chronic illness involving your central nervous system. Among other symptoms, it can cause vision problems (including scintillation), fatigue, dizziness, and headaches.

diagnoses.name: Intracranial hypertension
diagnoses.description: This condition, also known as high brain pressure, can cause headaches, nausea, pulsatile tinnitus, and transient visual obscurations which can resemble scintillation.

diagnoses.name: Migraine
diagnoses.description: A neurological condition characterized by intense headaches often accompanied by nausea, vomiting, and sensitivity to light and sound.

diagnoses.name: Migraine with Aura
diagnoses.description: A type of migraine that involves visual disturbances (scintillation) and other neurological symptoms before the headache begins.

diagnoses.name: Tension-Type Headache
diagnoses.description: A common type of headache characterized by a constant ache or pressure around the head, especially at the temples or back of the head and neck.

diagnoses.name: Cluster Headache
diagnoses.description: A condition that causes intense headaches on one side of the head, typically around the eye, and can be accompanied by symptoms like redness and watering of the eye, nasal congestion, and facial sweating.

diagnoses.name: Anemia
diagnoses.description: A condition characterized by a lack of healthy red blood cells, leading to fatigue and weakness among other symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Hypoglycemia
diagnoses.description: A condition caused by a very low level of blood sugar (glucose), leading to symptoms like weakness, trembling, and headaches.

diagnoses.name: Dehydration
diagnoses.description: A condition that occurs when you use or lose more fluid than you take in, and your body doesn't have enough water and other fluids to carry out its normal functions, possibly leading to headaches and weakness.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis
diagnoses.description: A disease of the brain and spinal cord (central nervous system) that can cause weakness, coordination and balance difficulties, and other neurological problems.

diagnoses.name: Viral Meningitis
diagnoses.description: An inflammation of the protective membranes covering the brain and spinal cord, known as the meninges. Symptoms can include headache, weakness, and sensitivity to light.

diagnoses.name: Subarachnoid Hemorrhage
diagnoses.description: Bleeding in the space between the brain and the tissue covering the brain, often signaled by a sudden, severe headache, along with other symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Migraine
diagnoses.description: A neurological condition characterized by intense headaches often accompanied by nausea, vomiting, and sensitivity to light and sound. In some cases, migraines can lead to aura, which might explain symptoms like aphasia.

diagnoses.name: Meniere's disease
diagnoses.description: A disorder of the inner ear causing episodes of spinning vertigo, hearing loss, tinnitus, and the sensation of fullness in the ear. Nausea can also occur during vertigo episodes.

diagnoses.name: Transient ischemic attack (TIA)
diagnoses.description: Often called a mini-stroke, a TIA produces stroke-like symptoms but lasts only a few minutes and causes no permanent damage. It could explain the sudden onset of aphasia and tinnitus.

diagnoses.name: Stroke
diagnoses.description: A condition where poor blood flow to the brain results in cell death. Symptoms can include aphasia and, depending on the area of the brain affected, could also involve tinnitus and nausea.

diagnoses.name: Acoustic neuroma
diagnoses.description: A benign tumor on the cranial nerve that affects balance and hearing. Main symptoms can include hearing loss, tinnitus, and imbalance leading to nausea.

diagnoses.name: Multiple sclerosis
diagnoses.description: A disease in which the immune system eats away at the protective covering of nerves. Symptoms can be wide-ranging and may include tinnitus, nausea, and, in more advanced cases, aphasia.

diagnoses.name: Brain tumor
diagnoses.description: A mass or growth of abnormal cells in your brain. Many symptoms are nonspecific but can include headaches, seizures, nausea, and depending on its location, possibly tinnitus or issues with speech such as aphasia.

diagnoses.name: Vestibular migraine
diagnoses.description: A type of migraine that might not always include a headache as a symptom but can cause dizziness, vertigo, phonophobia, and imbalance. Nausea and tinnitus are also common symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Basilar migraine
diagnoses.description: A rare form of migraine with aura symptoms, including tinnitus, dizziness, and sometimes speech disturbances and confusion. Nausea is a common symptom as well.

diagnoses.name: Post-concussion syndrome
diagnoses.description: A complex disorder in which various symptoms — such as headaches and dizziness — last for weeks and sometimes months after the injury that caused the concussion. It can include symptoms like tinnitus, light and sound sensitivity (phonophobia), nausea, and problems with speech and concentration.

diagnoses: DRESS Syndrome (Drug Reaction with Eosinophilia and Systemic Symptoms)
Stevens-Johnson Syndrome / Toxic Epidermal Necrolysis (as a differential for TEN)

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.rationale: This autoimmune disease commonly presents with oral ulcers, discoid rashes, and can also lead to neuropsychiatric manifestations such as psychosis. Lupus can cause widespread inflammation affecting various organs, including the skin and central nervous system.

diagnoses.name: Behçet's Disease
diagnoses.rationale: A rare disorder causing vascular inflammation throughout the body. Key symptoms include oral and genital ulcers, eye inflammation, and skin lesions that may resemble a discoid rash or non-scarring alopecia.

diagnoses.name: Lupus Erythematosus Tumidus
diagnoses.rationale: A subset of cutaneous lupus erythematosus that could present with nonscarring alopecia and skin rashes without the systemic involvement often seen in Systemic Lupus Erythematosus.

diagnoses.name: Discoid Lupus Erythematosus
diagnoses.rationale: A chronic autoimmune disease affecting the skin, presenting as discoid rashes that can lead to scarring, potentially explaining nonscarring alopecia if hair-bearing skin is affected.

diagnoses.name: Vasculitis
diagnoses.rationale: A group of disorders that destroy blood vessels by inflammation. Both cutaneous and systemic vasculitis can cause skin rashes, ulcers, and systemic symptoms. Some types might indirectly contribute to psychiatric symptoms like psychosis.

diagnoses.name: Sjögren's Syndrome
diagnoses.rationale: An autoimmune disease that attacks glands responsible for tears and saliva. It is associated with mucosal dryness leading to oral ulcers, and may also involve skin and psychiatric manifestations.

diagnoses.name: Rhinoscleroma
diagnoses.rationale: A chronic condition caused by Klebsiella rhinoscleromatis affecting the nose and upper respiratory tract, potentially leading to nasal ulcers, but less likely to be associated with the other symptoms unless complications or comorbid conditions are present.

diagnoses.name: Sarcoidosis
diagnoses.rationale: An inflammatory disease affecting multiple organs in the body, particularly the lungs and lymph glands. Skin manifestations like lupus pernio can mimic discoid rash, and neurological sarcoidosis can potentially lead to psychiatric symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Wegener's Granulomatosis (Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis)
diagnoses.rationale: A form of vasculitis that can cause nasal ulcers, and may occasionally present with skin manifestations and, rarely, neuropsychiatric symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Cutaneous Lupus Erythematosus
diagnoses.rationale: This encompasses a range of cutaneous conditions including discoid lupus erythematosus, predominantly affecting the skin but may have systemic manifestations or associations that could explain the complex symptomatology.

diagnoses: Hepatitis B or C with Cryoglobulinemia
Evans syndrome (autoimmune hemolytic anemia with immune thrombocytopenia)
Viral Infections (e.g., HIV, Hepatitis B, Hepatitis C)
Viral Infections (such as Epstein-Barr Virus, HIV)
Viral infections (such as HIV or Hepatitis)
